@mwgarbett This is 'Merica, Matt. We have parking everywhere.  On the left-hand side of the one-way street; on the right-hand side of the one-way street. In the alley-ways behind the houses. In the parking decks down the block. Everywhere.
@mwgarbett Because 'Merica, Matt.
@mwgarbett Technically, it's a road diet of sorts. This was a 2-lane one-way. They took away a lane (which we've pushed for) and put in the paint gobbledy gook.

@mwgarbett You're urbanisting from outside onto a blank map that isn't. 1-way is state's& already cost my city over a million in failed studies over past decade that could've been used 4 real city transport issues.
Not a thoroughfare: a bus road w/ lights/4ways every .1 mile & 30mph limit
@mwgarbett Better than I'd have done, but 1/7 off is not even getting you a point in horseshoes.

@mwgarbett @BeckyKatz96 1-way street. 

Not sure why a 2nd (2-way) lane is needed, which would push traffic toward the edges/bike lanes & create massive backup from left-hand turns on 2nd major northern exit out of city. Trust me on this, out o'towner.

@mwgarbett Looks like 31 feet and some leftover buffer in the middle.

Who knew, the wrench in our 1-way/2-way arguments remains...inept government.  Now that I see the sketch, though--is this bike lane also 1-way? NoC is pro 2-way bike lanes. https://t.co/bz0kW5tRcu

@mwgarbett Maybe the center-line paint was to bolster the bid cost? 

Or...it's Lex--maybe a grant-funded artistic gesture from some outside nonprofit?

@mwgarbett Most of that section is rarely even used for off-street parking anyway.  
Is there a right way to do paint on a major road?  Seems like waste of energy & (as a driver) dangerously confusing.
